webTitle: Rolls-Royce warns defence cuts to take toll on 2014 revenues and profits

fields.bodyText: Rolls-Royce has become the latest major UK company to warn on profits as the industrial group called an end to a decade of revenue growth and wiped more than £3bn off its share price. The Derby-based engine manufacturer joined Pearson, BG Group and Royal Bank of Scotland in surprising investors this year with an about-turn on earnings, predicting profits would be flat in 2014 owing to US defence cuts and the end of profitable contracts. Rolls-Royce stock slumped 13.6%, costing shareholders £3.1bn, but the company was only the second-biggest faller in the FTSE 100 index behind sweetener firm Tate & Lyle, which issued a profit warning and slipped 16%. They joined a string of companies that have jolted investors with grim trading updates this year even as the economy shows signs of improvement, with the strength of sterling among the most commonly cited factors for downward revisions to earnings. Announcing a "pause" in growth after a strong 2013, chief executive John Rishton said: "This is a break in a 10-year trend that will be followed by more growth in 2015. We have defied gravity for a couple of years compared with other defence companies and the impact of a couple of things is coming together in 2014." The world's second-biggest aircraft engine maker expects revenue to fall between 15% and 20% at its defence business and a small reduction in revenue but modest profit growth at its marine division. The defence arm will feel the effects of "well publicised cuts" in the US and the end of big orders in India and the Middle East, Rishton said. But Investors were left shocked by the grim trading update from a company that is normally a model for meeting market expectations. Tina Wood, an industry analyst at broker Charles Stanley, said: "For the past few years Rolls-Royce's defence business has been outperforming its defence peers. Analysts have been asking about that for the last two years so it's quite a shock for it to be downgraded so much. It's raised a lot of questions and that is clearly reflected in what has happened to the share price, which is dramatic, especially for a company such as Rolls-Royce." Rishton said: "Could we have done better? Yes we probably could. You reflect on it and you think maybe we need to do something different and that's what we have done." Rolls-Royce's underlying pre-tax profit for 2013, excluding an acquisition, rose 23% to £1.76bn – near the top of analyst forecasts. Rishton said a record order book of £71.6bn – up 19% – underpinned the group's prospects for many years to come and that a flat 2014 would be "a pause, not a change in direction". He said confidence on growth allowed Rolls-Royce to increase its annual dividend by 13% to 22p. Rishton declined to comment on two arrests made by the Serious Fraud Office on Wednesday in connection with an investigation into allegations of bribery in Indonesia and China. Neither of those arrested was a Rolls-Royce employee but were said to have been intermediaries used by the company. "It's a matter for the authorities," Rishton said. Rolls-Royce and Tate & Lyle, whose sucralose product is suffering from heavy competition in China, are the latest big UK firms to warn on trading this year. Royal Dutch Shell, BG Group and Pearson have all shaken investors with profit alerts along with Royal Bank of Scotland and retailers Morrisons and Mothercare. They were joined on Thursday by Swiss firms Nestlé, the world's biggest food company, and ABB, an engineering group, which warned of a sharp worsening of revenue prospects. Financial analyst Louise Cooper said Britain might be growing strongly but the world economy was still suffering from the after-effects of the financial crisis and the global recession that followed. "Tate & Lyle is a one-off and it doesn't tell us much about the world. What is more concerning is when companies are worrying about the top line, and to have three big companies warning about revenue today is a little concerning. Nestlé's chief executive calls Europe a no-growth environment with material negative pricing. That is quite worrying for something as basic as food from such a big company." British companies published 73 profit warnings in the final three months of 2013, up 30% on the previous quarter. The 350 biggest listed companies posted 31 warnings – as many as in the last quarter of 2008 when the world was on the brink of financial armageddon.Thursday brought three significant profit warnings that do not bode well for wider market prospects – two of them outside the UK. Alongside Rolls-Royce's revelation, Switzerland's Nestle, the world's biggest food company, and ABB, the automation giant, also issued grim outlooks on revenues. Financial analyst Louise Cooper said: "Tate & Lyle is a one-off and it doesn't tell us much about the world. What is more concerning is when companies are worrying about the top line, and to have three big companies warning about revenue today is a little concerning." "Nestle's chief executive calls Europe a no-growth environment with material negative pricing. That is quite worrying for something as basic as food from such a big company." A number of warnings, for example that relating to BG Group's problems in Egypt and the fallout from the scandal of Serco overcharging taxpayers, were specific to those companies. But many of the warnings indicate a global economy still suffering from the after-effects of the financial crash and the deep recession that followed – from government cutbacks to tumbling emerging market currencies and weak household spending power. The main retail casualties – Morrisons, Mothercare and Debenhams on New Year's Eve – suffered from their own shortcomings such as poor internet strategies compared with online converts such as Next and Argos. But the trio all suffered from cut-throat competition as squeezed UK consumers abandoned the middle ground and opted for cheaper options with a touch of luxury on top. Companies have become more global meaning shocks outside Britain economy – such as political unrest in the Middle East, turmoil in emerging markets and falling commodity prices – are more likely to affect UK firms. The FTSE 100 is no longer a barometer for the UK economy. Britain's leading companies now make almost 80% of their revenues overseas and 30% from emerging markets after they expanded overseas or foreign companies listed in London. For companies trading abroad, and particularly in emerging markets, the strengthening US and British economies are not necessarily a good thing. The falls in developing countries' currencies hit profits when they are translated into the buoyant pound or, in some cases, the dollar. Even smaller companies Mothercare and Hornby were hit by falling currencies in emerging markets. Iowan Smith, a strategist at Knight Capital Europe, said the picture was worse than it seemed because many companies have been guiding down expectations or cutting costs to meet forecasts on results day. He said: "Earnings growth expectations for the biggest European companies have collapsed from more than 9% at the start of December to 0% – i.e. no growth."

webTitle: Karen Millen opens new stores in bid to reinvent itself as a luxury brand

fields.standfirst: Outlets in Knightsbridge and New York will offer bespoke options and aim to make off-the-peg designs more exclusive
fields.body:
Karen Millen is to open its largest ever stores in Knightsbridge and New York at Easter as it reinvents itself as a luxury label without the designer prices.

The brand, which designs all its clothes at a couture-style atelier in Shoreditch, east London, will use the stores, near Harrods in London and on Fifth Avenue in New York, to launch a new image which ditches bling in favour of pared down, light stores.

The London shop, almost double the size of Karen Millen's current flagship, will offer bespoke garments which can be made to order, a service which Karen Millen wants to take worldwide.

"What we do is evolving because our clients' tastes evolve," said Mike Shearwood, chief executive of parent Aurora Fashions. "In the UK the perception of the brand had become very narrow but internationally it's not just about going out dresses. It's more of a total wardrobe."

The change in tack comes as the label, which already draws 70% of its sales from outside the UK, continues to expand abroad. It is set to move into Canada, Norway and India this year as it opens 40 new stores worldwide.

Bespoke studios will also appear abroad. The retailer is currently offering made-to-order leather jackets via a pop-up in Selfridges in London and similar projects are planned in Paris's Galeries Lafayette and stores in Amsterdam and New York later this year.

"What we've come to realise is that people want exclusivity. We are introducing more special pieces at higher price points and we've had incredible sell-throughs on some of those," said Gemma Metheringham, Karen Millen's creative director.

Shearwood said the business's wide geographic spread meant it could spread its off the peg designs thinly, offering women outfits they were unlikely to see worn by someone else.

"Even on a big production run for us of 4,000 units, when spread around 400 stores in 65 countries that leads to exclusivity which you just don't get elsewhere on the high street at the kind of prices we charge," says Shearwood.

webTitle: Australia’s housing bubble ready to burst, US investment guru claims

fields.standfirst: House prices set to plummet by up to 50% as ‘demographic crisis’ and falling Chinese demand looms
fields.body:
If you are one of the many thousands of Australians at risk of being priced out of the property market, you had better wish that Harry Dent has got his sums right.

Dent, an American investment guru who uses demographics to forecast economic cycles, thinks the soaring housing market is ready to burst any day now, perhaps reducing values by as much as 50% in some places.

Dent, who was in Sydney this week to promote his book The Demographic Cliff, has a formidable record. He claims credit for predicting Japan’s deflationary decade and the US boom and bust of the past 20 years, and has now turned his numbers on Australia.

“I don’t see an upside in Australian real estate but there is a lot of downside. If you are going to own a house and live in it forever then perhaps it’s OK to buy a house, but speculative property – don’t do it.”

With housing valued at 10 times average incomes – the same level as California’s just before the subprime crash – Dent thinks Australia is heading for a fall which will be sparked by a sharp reversal of the current global economic recovery.

“I see a decline in the 30-50% range across Australia, although it may vary from city to city,” he says.

“The rule with bubbles is that they always go back to where the bubble started. So the US housing bubble started to grow in 2000 and now house prices have fallen back to that point – a 55% fall.”

He is supremely confident that it will also happen here.

“Most people buying houses are aged between 28 and 41. When they can’t afford to buy a modest house for 800k as in Sydney, for example, then demand falls and real estate falls.”

While the many Australians with large mortgages might view Dent’s forecasts with alarm, he insists a crash would benefit the economy.

“People should be praying that real estate will fall because it’s not good for living standards and it’s not good for the economy to have such high prices.’’

As a young consultant working for Bain & Company, Dent’s job was to study consumer spending patterns for his clients, mostly small- and medium-sized businesses.

He discovered that he could predict what he calls the “spending wave” according to people’s age. At that time the postwar baby boom generation were having children and reaching the peak of their lifetime spending – not just on mortgages, but nappies, food, school fees and all the other extras that come with raising children.

The problem comes as that large generation passes its spending peak – at 46 in the US and about 47 in Australia, the UK and other western countries – and starts planning for retirement. This is the crux of his pessimistic world view.

“For the first time in history, the generation following is smaller. I spotted this first with Japan in 1988-89 where their demographics were turning. Everyone thought the 90s would see Japan pass the US and become the biggest economy in the world, but it collapsed and has been in deflation ever since,” he explains.

“The same thing is now happening in the US and Europe, especially southern Europe. Everyone thinks that in the current crisis we are fighting a debt bubble but it’s not a temporary financial crisis, it’s a demographic crisis.

“Now I go to South Korea, for example, and say to them ‘you are Japan on a 22-year lag’. The Korean market peaked last year and will now decline.’’

Many economists believe that this kind of doom-mongering is misplaced and that China, with its centrally controlled economy and huge cash reserves of more than US$2t, can keep on growing and drag the world with it.

But Dent is in no doubt which side he is on.

“We’ve had bubbles throughout our time – oil, gold, stocks. But China is the biggest bubble in modern history. It’s 30% overbuilt in everything and has huge over-investment. The housing market is valued at 28 to 35 times income in the major cities. London, by way of contrast, is 15 times.

“For people who say the government can control it, I say that’s bad. It means a bigger bubble and a bigger burst.”

Again, he sees demographics as the key.

“China’s growth peaks in 2012 and plateaus by 2023. Then it’s off the cliff. They’re desperately trying to move people from rural areas to the cities to increase their spending power but they won’t have the workforce to grow because the population is not growing fast enough.

“There’s so much over-capacity it will burst: 24% of condos in China are vacant,” he says, with the kind of big-picture flourish that has put him in great demand on his Australian trip. He is due to speak at the Secure Your Future investment conference in Sydney this weekend.

Dent sees falling Chinese demand leaking out into the economies of countries dependent on selling their commodities to the superpower, starting a vicious circle in which demand then falls for Chinese manufactured goods and spreads back.

So, look out Australia, which has had a larger “echo boom”, as Dent calls it, than most. But he has an uncharacteristically optimistic view for Australia, which he thinks will do better than most thanks to its demographics – he sees the population reaching 36-38m by 2060, which is not as high as a recent government study found. Low government debt and mineral wealth will inevitably help the economy grow again in the next commodity cycle, he believes.

Then there is the wildcard of China’s ultrawealthy, more than half of whom now have investments overseas, according to a study by Bain & Company and quoted by Dent.

They are already recognised as having helped inflate house prices in Australia and Dent believes they are motivated by the prospect of collapse at home.

“The rich think that if it goes wrong, they’ll come after us. The rich Chinese want to move to London, New York, California, Sydney, educate their kids. But if the rich leave, where does that leave the property market in China?

“This is the wildcard, so it might keep prices up in Australia.

“But there will come a point when the Chinese government will not allow them to move so much money out. More are emigrating to get around the current limit of $50,000 a year but the government could get stricter and say ‘we can’t afford it, we’re going to stop you’.”

This conclusion offers some hope to those who want prices to fall and some to those who want to see their investments grow. Dent says he will apologise if he’s proved wrong, which he acknowledges could happen if central banks revert to their printing presses rather than slowing monetary stimulus as many are now doing.

“If we don’t see something starting to crack soon, a 20-30% fall in the stock market, for example, I’ll apologise. Governments will have pulled it off again and kicked the can down the road.

“It’s much easier being bullish than bearish.”

webTitle: Gyms, bars and bookies taking over high streets

fields.bodyText: Retail space equalling the size of the vast Westfield shopping centre in west London was converted to new uses last year, as the UK's high streets adapted to changing habits. Traditional shop space in excess of 1.7m sq ft was lost in 2013 – an increase of more than 60% on 2012 – as betting shops, gyms, bars and restaurants moved into vacant retail premises, according to a report for the industry journal Estates Gazette. Betting shops were the single most prolific type of new entrant, with 106 winning permission to open last year – but gyms and health clubs took up the most space, at more than 1m sq ft. The UK's high streets are undergoing a rapid transformation, as shoppers trim their spending and buy more online but continue to look for local leisure services and experiences. Change has also been driven by variations in the planning rules, which came into force in May last year and made it easier for developers to change the use of buildings. webTitle: Rolls-Royce has finally had to bow to modern practice

fields.bodyText: Rolls-Royce is a business where most of the cards, in theory, are on the table. The order book stands at an astonishing £71.6bn, the contracts can span decades and significant new additional work is announced when the paperwork is signed. It is the ultimate long-term business. It would not be possible, you might think, for Rolls-Royce to say anything about revenues that could send the share price down 14%. The above analysis, however, ignores the essential point that Rolls-Royce has never been terribly interested in what City analysts put in their multiyear spreadsheets. Rolls-Royce's style has been to talk only about "in year" profits. So in 2013 it was happy to opine on how well 2013 was going (guidance was raised twice) but it stayed silent on the outlook for 2014. Now that 2014 has arrived chief executive John Rishton has spoken, and has delivered a shocker: revenues and profit will be flat for the first time in a decade. Rolls-Royce had been "defying gravity" in 2013, he said, but cuts in defence budgets in the US and Europe are now biting. Cue much moaning in the City about cack-handed communications and a lack of disclosure. The grumble is only half-justified. An alternative view is that it is quite refreshing that there are still companies who decline to play the game of quietly massaging the City's expectations. For all that, yesterday was the moment Rolls-Royce was obliged to abandon glorious indifference to the City's demands and bow to modern practice. Thus Rishton offered shareholders the comfort that growth in revenues and profits will resume in 2015 after this year's "pause". If that forecast turns out to be correct, he's off the hook. Now that he's started the forecasting lark, he'd better be right. The deeper worry, actually, is that Rolls-Royce, after a decade of blistering growth (the order book has quadrupled since 2003 and the shares have soared), will have to learn a few new tricks if western governments continue to keep a lid on defence budgets. Top of the "to-do" list is to match arch-rival GE's production efficiencies. "It will take time and tenacity to drive cost out of the business, and we are still not where we need to be," admitted Rishton. Rolls-Royce remains a terrific business – but that sounds like a slight splutter.

webTitle: Shell to sell three North Sea oil assets

fields.standfirst: Anglo-Dutch oil company to dispose of Anasuria, Nelson and Sean platforms but is keen to deny move is influenced by politics
fields.body:
Shell is to sell off three oil and gas producing assets in the North Sea as the new chief executive's divestment gathers pace. The disposal of the Anasuria, Nelson and Sean platforms and production systems come at a sensitive political time when other energy bosses have signalled that the forthcoming referendum on Scottish independence is undermining the investment climate.

Shell was keen to deny that the move was influenced by politics, or that the Anglo-Dutch company was not committed to a UK North Sea sector where overall production has fallen by two thirds since 2000.

Glen Cayley, vice-president for Upstream Shell UK and Ireland said: "The UK is an important business region for Shell, and our investment strategy continues to focus on assets where we see an opportunity for growth using our world-class technological know-how."

He added: "We are talking to staff about the proposal to sell the assets in order to be as open as possible, whilst confirming our commitment to the North Sea."

But the pullback will increase nervousness both inside the industry and out. The UK Oil & Gas lobby group has warned the government that steps need to be taken if a steep decline in oil and gas output is to be reversed.

Meanwhile, Bob Dudley, chief executive of BP, last week gave the starkest warning yet that the business sector does not like the kind of political uncertainty created by the September referendum. Scottish politicians have made clear they would stake a claim to the vast bulk of Britain's oil and gas reserves in the event of a vote for independence.

• This article was amended on 14 February 2014. An earlier version appeared to suggest that Shell said it may not be committed to the UK North Sea sector. This has been corrected.

webTitle: Italian PM to resign after centre-left leader Matteo Renzi calls for new government – as it happened

fields.standfirst:
• Closing summary: Enrico Letta quits
  • Letta to tender resignation tomorrow
  • Matteo Renzi likely to succeed him after dramatic speech today
  • Early reaction
fields.body:
6.43pm GMT

Italian PM Enrico Letta to resign

And finally, from Rome, here’s our correspondent Lizzy Davies on the latest drama in Italian politics:

Italy‘s prime minister, Enrico Letta, will resign on Friday after his centre-left party voted heavily in favour of backing his rival’s call for a new government, a “new phase” and a “radical programme” of reform.

Minutes after the Democratic party’s (PD) national committee backed the 39-year-old Florence mayor Matteo Renzi’s proposal by 136 votes to 16, with two abstentions, Palazzo Chigi - the official residence of the prime minister - said Letta would be going to the Quirinale on Friday to tender his resignation to President Giorgio Napolitano.

Letta’s government, which came into being after an unprecedented period of uncertainty following inconclusive elections in February, had been in power for nine-and-a-half months. Renzi, who became leader of the PD in December, is now almost certain to take over as prime minister.

In a speech earlier, Renzi had paid tribute to Letta’s government, saying the meeting was not intended to put it “on trial”. But, without directly proposing himself as the next premier, he said the eurozone’s third-largest economy urgently needed “a new phase” and “radical programme” to push through reforms.

The motion made clear “the necessity and urgency of opening a new phase with a new executive”.

The two Tuscan politicians had been engaged in an intense power struggle for days.

More here: Italian PM Enrico Letta to resign

Reminder - you can scroll back to 1.29pm GMT onwards for highlights of Matteo Renzi’s dramatic speech, and 5.08pm GMT onwards to see how the news of Letta’s resignation broke.

That’s a good morning moment to stop the blog.

I’ll be back tomorrow morning to cover the latest developments in Italy, and lots of GDP data from across the eurozone showing which countries grew and which shrunk in the final quarter of 2013.

Until then, thanks, and goodnight. GW.

Updated at 6.54pm GMT

6.24pm GMT

Silvio Berlusconi, who quit Letta’s government with a rump of loyal MPs, will also attend tomorrow’s meeting at the presidential palace to choose a new prime minister.

6.21pm GMT

Alfano: we're taking nothing for granted

Interesting.... Angelino Alfano, who leads the centre-right faction in the current Italian coalition, has given cautious support to Matteo Renzi, but cautioned that he can’t guarantee reaching a deal with him.

Here’s the snaps:

  • ITALY COALITION PARTNER ALFANO SAYS APPRECIATES “CLARITY” OF RENZI’S PROPOSAL AND FACT WANTS TO KEEP SAME RULING COALITION
  • ITALY COALITION PARTNER ALFANO SAYS SUPPORT FOR RENZI DEPENDS ON AGREEMENT OVER POLICY
  • ITALY COALITION PARTNER ALFANO SAYS RENZI GOVERNMENT MUST LAST AS LONG AS NECESSARY TO COMPLETE REFORMS, NOT NECESSARILY UNTIL 2018
  • ITALY COALITION PARTNER ALFANO SAYS WANTS TO SEE IF CAN WORK WITH RENZI ON ON LABOUR MARKET, TAX POLICY
  • ITALY COALITION PARTNER ALFANO SAYS TAKING NOTHING FOR GRANTED AND NOT SURE THAT ATTEMPT TO FORM NEW GOVT WILL SUCCEED

Political analysts have suggested that neither side would want to return to the polls until electoral law changes have been pushed through.

6.07pm GMT

6.06pm GMT

What went wrong for Enrico Letta?

Cast your mind back a year, and no-one was suggesting that the former MEP and Italian minister would become prime minister. Then, the PD party, led by Pier-Luigi Bersani, was heading for victory in the general election. But a late rally for Silvio Berlusconi, and a surge of support for Beppe Grillo’s radical Five Star movement, left no party with a clear majority.

After weeks of deadlock, president Napolitano managed to hammer out a deal where PD and Berlusconi’s PDL would form an uneasy coalition with Letta - a senior member of PD - at the helm.

In his early months Letta was pretty outspoken about the need to fight youth unemployment, warning of the damage that harsh austerity was causing in Europe’s periphery. But much of his time was dominated by Berlusconi, who threatened to bring down Letta’s government in anger at being convicted for tax fraud.

Letta won that battle -- dramatically winning a confidence vote in October 2013. Berlusconi’s party subsequently split, but enough MPs stayed within the coalition to keep Letta in power.

But Letta has not managed to push through many reforms - and has looked increasingly bogged down in recent months. The easing of the eurozone crisis has, paradoxically, meant less pressure to take unpopular decisions.

It can’t have been a pleasant nine months either. As Lizzy Davies wrote in today’s paper:

Recalling the “crisis situation” in which his government was formed last year, Letta said he had always considered it to be “a government of service” and appeared at pains to stress how unusually difficult his period as prime minister had been, repeatedly declaring he had been living “each day as if it was the last”.

Updated at 6.12pm GMT

5.50pm GMT

Letta out. Renzi in?

Here’s how the newswires are reporting the news:

Associated Press

Italian Premier Enrico Letta says he is resigning after a party rival withdrew crucial government support.

Letta said Thursday that he will hand in his resignation to Italy’s president on Friday.

Letta was virtually forced to resign after his Democratic Party’s leader, Florence Mayor Matteo Renzi, pulled support for Letta’s tattered, 10-month-old governing coalition.
Renzi wants to be premier.

Reuters

Italian Prime Minister Enrico Letta will tender his resignation on Friday after his Democratic Party (PD) called for him to step aside to make way for a new government, a statement from the premier’s office said.

Letta will hand his resignation to President Giorgio Napolitano, who is widely expected to ask PD leader Matteo Renzi to form a new government.

5.42pm GMT

5.40pm GMT

At just 39, Matteo Renzi would be the youngest PM in Italy’s history -- continuing the generational change begun by Enrico Letta himself, who took office aged 46.

5.36pm GMT

More reaction:

5.33pm GMT

Matteo Renzi would also become the third unelected Italian prime minister in a row -- following Mario Monti (installed in November 2011 after Silvio Berlusconi’s government collapse) and Letta himself (chosen after last February’s general election delivered a split parliament).

Updated at 5.34pm GMT

5.30pm GMT

Assuming Matteo Renzi is invited to become PM, his next task will be to form a cabinet, and then win a confidence vote in the Italian parliament.

That shouldn’t be a serious obstacle - the coalition has a healthy enough majority, as long as the centre-right MPs who also form the government back him.

But then the hard work begins - Renzi had painted himself as the man who can shake up Italian politics, demolishing the bad old ways and pushing through the economic reforms that are desperately needed. Delivering that vision will require talent, vision, and guts.

5.26pm GMT

Once Enrico Letta tenders his resignation tomorrow, president Georgio Napolitano must choose a new leader.

It seems inevitable that he will pick Matteo Renzi -- the Democratic Party are the largest member of the current coalition.

Napolitano may not be impressed by the way Renzi has forced Letta out of office after just nine months -- the president was famously brought close to tears last April during the battle to form a new government.

5.15pm GMT

ITALIAN PM TO RESIGN

IT’S OFFICIAL: Enrico Letta will resign, after seeing his Democratic Party back Matteo Renzi’s call for a new government in the last few minutes.

Reuters had the news first:

LETTA WILL TENDER RESIGNATION TO NAPOLITANO ON FRIDAY - PM OFFICE STATEMENT - REUTERS

5.13pm GMT

PD backs Matteo Renzi's call for new Italian government

THE RESULT IS IN: The Democratic Party have backed Matteo Renzi’s call for a new government, and for prime minister Enrico Letta to step aside.

And it’s a landslide result -- a total of 136 members voted in favour, with just 16 against, and 2 abstaining.

As covered at 2.39pm onwards, Renzi made a passionate call for change in Italian politics, and a new phase to tackle the country’s economic problems

5.08pm GMT

It’s getting tense over in Italy....

5.01pm GMT

Pound and gold up as dollar suffers

The dollar has weakened today, since the worst-than-expected retail sales and jobless claims data was released at 1.30pm GMT.

This pushed the gold price back over $1,300 for the first time since November, and drove the pound to a two and a half-year high of $1.667.

4.56pm GMT

There’s a hefty police presence outside the Democratic Party headquarters as the leadership meeting continues:

4.47pm GMT

A calm end to trading in Milan -- the FTSE MIB closing down just 0.2%. Italian politics appears to have lost the power to shock traders.

And Italian bonds are also unshaken - trading slightly higher tonight, which has pushed down the yield on 10-year debt to 3.71%, from 3.73% yesterday.

4.14pm GMT

3.44pm GMT

The Democratic Party committee is expected vote later today on whether to back Matteo Renzi’s call for a new government (effectively a vote of no confidence in prime minister Letta)

3.36pm GMT

Markets calm

There is no panic, at all, in the financial markets over the prospect of the Italian prime minister being forced to resign.

Italian 10-year bond yields (the measure of how much it costs the country to borrow) are actually slightly LOWER this afternoon at 3.72%.

Two years ago, Silvio Berlusconi was ejected from office when those yields soared over 7% - showing Italy was losing the ability to finance its own debts.

Since then, Mario Monti and then Enrico Letta have pushed some structural reforms though. The big change, though, is that the European Central Bank pledged to do “whatever it takes” to save the eurozone -- by buying unlimited quantities of short-term debt if needed.

In Milan, the main Italian stock market (the FTSE MIB) is only down 0.7% - in line with other markets today.

3.27pm GMT

It’s all terribly Italian:

3.23pm GMT

A series of senior party members have been speaking (livefeed here), and broadly backing Matteo Renzi’s call for change.

3.21pm GMT

Need to get up to speed on the latest Italian political crisis? Then check out Lizzy Davies’s piece in today’s paper - it explains how Matteo Renzi has been firing steady criticism at Enrico Letta since becoming head of the PD party in December*.

Italian PM Enrico Letta’s government in danger of collapse

(Renzi had originally LOST the race to become PD leader in December 2012. His victor, Pier-Luigi Bersani, then botched the job of winning the general election in Spring 2013, and was later ousted. That election produced a hung parliament, leading [eventually] to Enrico Letta being summoned to become coalition PM).

3.15pm GMT

Renzi's speech - reaction

Here’s some instant reaction to Matteo Renzi’s call for a new Italian government:

3.06pm GMT

Reuters: Renzi piles pressure on Letta to resign

Here’s Reuters early take

Italian centre-left leader Matteo Renzi on Thursday piled pressure on Prime Minister Enrico Letta to resign, telling his Democratic Party (PD) at a leadership meeting that Italy needs a new government.

Renzi is widely expected to succeed Letta as prime minister if the PD leadership approves his proposal at the end of the meeting.

Renzi called for “a new phase with a new government backed by the same coalition forces.”

Renzi thanked Letta, who is also a member of the PD, for his service to the country and said snap elections were not the best way forward for Italy.

<end>

As mentioned earlier this afternoon, Letta has cancelled two trips to European countries later this month -- fuelling speculation that his future is in doubt.

Updated at 3.06pm GMT

2.59pm GMT

Renzi makes pitch for the premiership

So what has Matteo Renzi said, and what does it mean?

The rising talent of centre-left Italian politics (compared to Blair or Schröder in some quarters) has demanded a change of political direction and a “new government”, but not new elections.

That, political analyst Alberdo Nardelli says, means one thing -- Renzi is making his pitch to become Italy’s next prime minister, for the long haul too.

PD are one of the two partners in the current coalition, along with a centre-right group led by Angelino Alfano, Silvio Berlusconi’s former right-hand man.

Renzi just finished speaking - and was received with warm applause from the PD audience.

Updated at 3.03pm GMT

2.54pm GMT

Matteo Renzi (seen by some as Italy’s best hope of a reforming leader) went on to warn that Italy’s credibility is at risk, if the situation does not change.

(critics of Enrico Letta say he has failed to drive through structural reforms over a nine-month period dominated by the travails of Silvio Berlusconi)

2.50pm GMT

In other words, he’s arguing against a snap election -- suggesting that Democratic Party should NOT withdraw from the current government and trigger another ballot.

Launching a new government in the current parliament would also be risky, he adds.

Updated at 6.42pm GMT

Tapping the lectern firmly at one stage, Matteo Renzi thanked Enrico Letta for his work as prime minister since April 2013.

He then talks about the need to open a new phase in Italian politics!

US retail sales are also weaker than expected, helping to push shares down in Europe (Wall Street opens under 30 minutes).

Sales fell 0.4% in January (against expectations of a flat reading), and were unchanged if you stripped out sales of new cars. November and December’s figures were also revised down.

Analysts at Capital Economics say the drop suggests the US recovery was less robust:

January’s US retail sales data suggest that fourth-quarter GDP growth may be revised down by an additional 0.1 ppts and that first-quarter growth may be weaker than we previously thought.

James Knightley of ING pointed to the recent (ongoing) bad weather in the US:

Furniture sales fell 0.6%, as did health and personal care with clothing down 0.9%, sporting goods down 1.4% and eating and drinking retailers saw sales fall 0.6%. This is more understandable given the “polar vortex” clearly disrupted retailers activities and deterred consumers from going out to shop.

Here’s what Tina Cook, an analyst at Charles Stanley, told Sean:

Italian political turmoil....

On the eurozone front - it could be a dramatic day in Italy. The Democratic Party (PD) could be poised to whip away its support from coalition leader Enrico Letta in a move that would put its own leader, Matteo Renzi, in power.

Italian PM Enrico Letta’s government in danger of collapse

Lloyds CEO defends bonus

While Lloyds staff are sharing £395m in bonuses, CEO Antonio Horta-Osorio is personally taking home £1.7m after hitting his targets - including keeping Lloyds’ share price over the level at which the government could sell its stake without making a loss.

Chief executive Antonio Horta-Osorio sounds upbeat this morning -- saying the results should help the taxpayer to shed its large stake in Lloyds (acquired when the bank was rescued in the financial crisis)

These results, with Group underlying profit more than doubled to £6.2 billion, confirm that the Group is returning to robust health, thanks to the commitment of our people and the consistent execution of the strategy we set out in June 2011.

Comcast in $44bn bid for Time Warner Cable

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of events across the financial markets, the economy, the eurozone and business.

Two big corporate news stories to start the morning -- a mega deal that will combine America’s two biggest cable companies, and the long-awaited return to profitability at one of Britain’s largest banks.

CNBC, which broke the deal earlier this morning, explains:

fields.bodyText: And finally, from Rome, here’s our correspondent Lizzy Davies on the latest drama in Italian politics: Italy‘s prime minister, Enrico Letta, will resign on Friday after his centre-left party voted heavily in favour of backing his rival’s call for a new government, a “new phase” and a “radical programme” of reform. Minutes after the Democratic party’s (PD) national committee backed the 39-year-old Florence mayor Matteo Renzi’s proposal by 136 votes to 16, with two abstentions, Palazzo Chigi - the official residence of the prime minister - said Letta would be going to the Quirinale on Friday to tender his resignation to President Giorgio Napolitano. Letta’s government, which came into being after an unprecedented period of uncertainty following inconclusive elections in February, had been in power for nine-and-a-half months. Renzi, who became leader of the PD in December, is now almost certain to take over as prime minister. In a speech earlier, Renzi had paid tribute to Letta’s government, saying the meeting was not intended to put it “on trial”. But, without directly proposing himself as the next premier, he said the eurozone’s third-largest economy urgently needed “a new phase” and “radical programme” to push through reforms. The motion made clear “the necessity and urgency of opening a new phase with a new executive”. The two Tuscan politicians had been engaged in an intense power struggle for days. More here: Italian PM Enrico Letta to resign Reminder - you can scroll back to 1.29pm GMT onwards for highlights of Matteo Renzi’s dramatic speech, and 5.08pm GMT onwards to see how the news of Letta’s resignation broke. That’s a good morning moment to stop the blog. I’ll be back tomorrow morning to cover the latest developments in Italy, and lots of GDP data from across the eurozone showing which countries grew and which shrunk in the final quarter of 2013. Until then, thanks, and goodnight. GW. Silvio Berlusconi, who quit Letta’s government with a rump of loyal MPs, will also attend tomorrow’s meeting at the presidential palace to choose a new prime minister. Interesting.... Angelino Alfano, who leads the centre-right faction in the current Italian coalition, has given cautious support to Matteo Renzi, but cautioned that he can’t guarantee reaching a deal with him. Here’s the snaps: ITALY COALITION PARTNER ALFANO SAYS APPRECIATES “CLARITY” OF RENZI’S PROPOSAL AND FACT WANTS TO KEEP SAME RULING COALITION ITALY COALITION PARTNER ALFANO SAYS SUPPORT FOR RENZI DEPENDS ON AGREEMENT OVER POLICY ITALY COALITION PARTNER ALFANO SAYS RENZI GOVERNMENT MUST LAST AS LONG AS NECESSARY TO COMPLETE REFORMS, NOT NECESSARILY UNTIL 2018 ITALY COALITION PARTNER ALFANO SAYS WANTS TO SEE IF CAN WORK WITH RENZI ON ON LABOUR MARKET, TAX POLICY ITALY COALITION PARTNER ALFANO SAYS TAKING NOTHING FOR GRANTED AND NOT SURE THAT ATTEMPT TO FORM NEW GOVT WILL SUCCEED Political analysts have suggested that neither side would want to return to the polls until electoral law changes have been pushed through. What went wrong for Enrico Letta? Cast your mind back a year, and no-one was suggesting that the former MEP and Italian minister would become prime minister. Then, the PD party, led by Pier-Luigi Bersani, was heading for victory in the general election. But a late rally for Silvio Berlusconi, and a surge of support for Beppe Grillo’s radical Five Star movement, left no party with a clear majority. After weeks of deadlock, president Napolitano managed to hammer out a deal where PD and Berlusconi’s PDL would form an uneasy coalition with Letta - a senior member of PD - at the helm. In his early months Letta was pretty outspoken about the need to fight youth unemployment, warning of the damage that harsh austerity was causing in Europe’s periphery. But much of his time was dominated by Berlusconi, who threatened to bring down Letta’s government in anger at being convicted for tax fraud. Letta won that battle -- dramatically winning a confidence vote in October 2013. Berlusconi’s party subsequently split, but enough MPs stayed within the coalition to keep Letta in power. But Letta has not managed to push through many reforms - and has looked increasingly bogged down in recent months. The easing of the eurozone crisis has, paradoxically, meant less pressure to take unpopular decisions. It can’t have been a pleasant nine months either. As Lizzy Davies wrote in today’s paper: Recalling the “crisis situation” in which his government was formed last year, Letta said he had always considered it to be “a government of service” and appeared at pains to stress how unusually difficult his period as prime minister had been, repeatedly declaring he had been living “each day as if it was the last”. Here’s how the newswires are reporting the news: Associated Press Italian Premier Enrico Letta says he is resigning after a party rival withdrew crucial government support. Letta said Thursday that he will hand in his resignation to Italy’s president on Friday. Letta was virtually forced to resign after his Democratic Party’s leader, Florence Mayor Matteo Renzi, pulled support for Letta’s tattered, 10-month-old governing coalition. Renzi wants to be premier. Reuters Italian Prime Minister Enrico Letta will tender his resignation on Friday after his Democratic Party (PD) called for him to step aside to make way for a new government, a statement from the premier’s office said. Letta will hand his resignation to President Giorgio Napolitano, who is widely expected to ask PD leader Matteo Renzi to form a new government. At just 39, Matteo Renzi would be the youngest PM in Italy’s history -- continuing the generational change begun by Enrico Letta himself, who took office aged 46. More reaction: Matteo Renzi would also become the third unelected Italian prime minister in a row -- following Mario Monti (installed in November 2011 after Silvio Berlusconi’s government collapse) and Letta himself (chosen after last February’s general election delivered a split parliament). Assuming Matteo Renzi is invited to become PM, his next task will be to form a cabinet, and then win a confidence vote in the Italian parliament. That shouldn’t be a serious obstacle - the coalition has a healthy enough majority, as long as the centre-right MPs who also form the government back him. But then the hard work begins - Renzi had painted himself as the man who can shake up Italian politics, demolishing the bad old ways and pushing through the economic reforms that are desperately needed. Delivering that vision will require talent, vision, and guts. Once Enrico Letta tenders his resignation tomorrow, president Georgio Napolitano must choose a new leader. It seems inevitable that he will pick Matteo Renzi -- the Democratic Party are the largest member of the current coalition. Napolitano may not be impressed by the way Renzi has forced Letta out of office after just nine months -- the president was famously brought close to tears last April during the battle to form a new government. IT’S OFFICIAL: Enrico Letta will resign, after seeing his Democratic Party back Matteo Renzi’s call for a new government in the last few minutes. Reuters had the news first: LETTA WILL TENDER RESIGNATION TO NAPOLITANO ON FRIDAY - PM OFFICE STATEMENT - REUTERS THE RESULT IS IN: The Democratic Party have backed Matteo Renzi’s call for a new government, and for prime minister Enrico Letta to step aside. And it’s a landslide result -- a total of 136 members voted in favour, with just 16 against, and 2 abstaining. As covered at 2.39pm onwards, Renzi made a passionate call for change in Italian politics, and a new phase to tackle the country’s economic problems It’s getting tense over in Italy.... The dollar has weakened today, since the worst-than-expected retail sales and jobless claims data was released at 1.30pm GMT. This pushed the gold price back over $1,300 for the first time since November, and drove the pound to a two and a half-year high of $1.667. There’s a hefty police presence outside the Democratic Party headquarters as the leadership meeting continues: A calm end to trading in Milan -- the FTSE MIB closing down just 0.2%. Italian politics appears to have lost the power to shock traders. And Italian bonds are also unshaken - trading slightly higher tonight, which has pushed down the yield on 10-year debt to 3.71%, from 3.73% yesterday. The Democratic Party committee is expected vote later today on whether to back Matteo Renzi’s call for a new government (effectively a vote of no confidence in prime minister Letta) There is no panic, at all, in the financial markets over the prospect of the Italian prime minister being forced to resign. Italian 10-year bond yields (the measure of how much it costs the country to borrow) are actually slightly LOWER this afternoon at 3.72%. Two years ago, Silvio Berlusconi was ejected from office when those yields soared over 7% - showing Italy was losing the ability to finance its own debts. Since then, Mario Monti and then Enrico Letta have pushed some structural reforms though. The big change, though, is that the European Central Bank pledged to do “whatever it takes” to save the eurozone -- by buying unlimited quantities of short-term debt if needed. In Milan, the main Italian stock market (the FTSE MIB) is only down 0.7% - in line with other markets today. It’s all terribly Italian: A series of senior party members have been speaking (livefeed here), and broadly backing Matteo Renzi’s call for change. Need to get up to speed on the latest Italian political crisis? Then check out Lizzy Davies’s piece in today’s paper - it explains how Matteo Renzi has been firing steady criticism at Enrico Letta since becoming head of the PD party in December*. Italian PM Enrico Letta’s government in danger of collapse (Renzi had originally LOST the race to become PD leader in December 2012. His victor, Pier-Luigi Bersani, then botched the job of winning the general election in Spring 2013, and was later ousted. That election produced a hung parliament, leading [eventually] to Enrico Letta being summoned to become coalition PM). Here’s some instant reaction to Matteo Renzi’s call for a new Italian government: Here’s Reuters early take Italian centre-left leader Matteo Renzi on Thursday piled pressure on Prime Minister Enrico Letta to resign, telling his Democratic Party (PD) at a leadership meeting that Italy needs a new government. Renzi is widely expected to succeed Letta as prime minister if the PD leadership approves his proposal at the end of the meeting. Renzi called for “a new phase with a new government backed by the same coalition forces.” Renzi thanked Letta, who is also a member of the PD, for his service to the country and said snap elections were not the best way forward for Italy.  As mentioned earlier this afternoon, Letta has cancelled two trips to European countries later this month -- fuelling speculation that his future is in doubt. So what has Matteo Renzi said, and what does it mean? The rising talent of centre-left Italian politics (compared to Blair or Schröder in some quarters) has demanded a change of political direction and a “new government”, but not new elections. That, political analyst Alberdo Nardelli says, means one thing -- Renzi is making his pitch to become Italy’s next prime minister, for the long haul too. PD are one of the two partners in the current coalition, along with a centre-right group led by Angelino Alfano, Silvio Berlusconi’s former right-hand man. Renzi just finished speaking - and was received with warm applause from the PD audience. Matteo Renzi (seen by some as Italy’s best hope of a reforming leader) went on to warn that Italy’s credibility is at risk, if the situation does not change. (critics of Enrico Letta say he has failed to drive through structural reforms over a nine-month period dominated by the travails of Silvio Berlusconi) Matteo Renzi says Italy’s outdated electoral system mean it wouldn’t be possible to hold a “successful” vote right now. In other words, he’s arguing against a snap election -- suggesting that Democratic Party should NOT withdraw from the current government and trigger another ballot. fields.bodyText: Lloyds Banking Group has awarded its chief executive António Horta-Osório a £1.7m bonus after declaring itself "a normal bank" five years after its bailout. With preparations under way for a sale of the taxpayer's remaining 33% stake, Horta-Osório played down the impact of Scottish independence on the bailed-out bank, which owns Bank of Scotland. The Portuguese banker – who took the top job in March 2011 – was forced to defend his decision to accept the bonus after union leaders called on him to follow rivals at Royal Bank of Scotland and Barclays and waive his payout. Horta-Osório pointed to last year's 70% rise in the share price, which allowed the government to sell off part of its stake last September. There are expectations that a further share sale could begin after the annual report is published on 6 March. "We are ready to proceed," he said. "The market, I think, is ready as well. I came to Lloyds three years ago to fix this bank and help taxpayers get their money back." He said he had stabilised the bank after its "quite precarious" position when he took charge, and declared that Lloyds was now "a normal bank". But TUC general secretary Frances O'Grady was unimpressed. "With Lloyds still owing billions to the taxpayer and the amount it has had to set aside for PPI mis-selling rising by a whopping £1.8bn, now is not the time for its chief executive to be taking a multimillion-pound bonus." Unite national officer Rob MacGregor said the payout to the boss – in a year when staff pay rose 2% and after 35,000 roles had been lost since the 2008 bailout – was a "kick in the teeth to the taxpayer". Horta-Osório will receive the £1.7m share bonus only if half of the remaining taxpayer holding is sold or if the share price remains above 73.6p – the breakeven point of the taxpayer bailout – for six months. He will then be required to hold the shares until 2019. A bonus pool of £395m will be shared between 91,000 staff and payouts will average £4,500 per worker. The bank insisted the payout pot had been reduced as a result of the bank's vast bill for compensating customers for mis-selling payment protection insurance – which has now reached nearly £10bn – and last year's £28m fine from the Financial Conduct Authority for a "champagne" bonus culture that potentially encouraged mis-selling. The bank reported a statutory profit of £415m – and a loss of £802m after tax – after being rocked by a £3bn charge for PPI mis-selling. It admitted a week ago that its total PPI mis-selling bill is now £9.8bn and former boss Eric Daniels is among those facing a potential clawback of bonuses after the bigger than expected compensation claims. Lloyds reported a £606m loss a year ago while the underlying profit for 2013 was £6.2bn, double a year ago. Horta-Osório's bonus comes on top of his £1m salary, £500,000 pension contribution and a payout from a long-term incentive plan that could total £2.9m – half the potential sum – when it is formally revealed next month. He has now begun work on a new three-year strategic plan for the bank, which is being forced to spin off its TSB brand under the terms of its bailout, in a move that could signal branch closures. Simon Walker, director general of the Institute of Directors, which on Tuesday blasted Barclays for paying higher bonuses when profits were falling, said Lloyds needed to be "sensitive to taxpayer perceptions when making decisions on remuneration and bonuses". Horta-Osório agreed it was a "bad principle" to pay out higher bonuses when profits were down as Barclays had done. Following calls by Ed Miliband to shake up high street banking by create two new players, Horta-Osório said this would be achieved by TSB – to be floated in the coming months – and the separation of Williams & Glyn's from RBS. However, the Lloyds boss conceded that competition was more of a concern in the small business banking market, currently being reviewed by the Office of Fair Trading. The shares closed down 2% at 81.32p. The bank warned last week that it would not be able to resume dividends until towards the end of this year, later than some analysts had hoped. Ian Gordon, banks analyst at Investec, said: "The statutory losses are heavier than had been assumed and the forward guidance is softer than frothier market expectations". Fine fears at BNP BNP Paribas, France's biggest listed bank, has set aside $1.1bn (£660m) to cover a possible fine for breaching US sanctions on countries including Iran, the latest bank to take a hit to profit from a legal investigation. Banks across the world are under investigation for a string of alleged misdeeds, including fixing benchmark interest rates and manipulating foreign exchange markets. They are also facing tougher rules in the wake of the financial crisis. This month, Credit Suisse set aside SFr514m (£346m) to cover US investigations, while in January Deutsche Bank blamed legal costs for a surprise quarterly loss. BNP said on Thursday it had set aside the funds after talks with the US authorities, though it said there had been no discussion on the size of any potential penalty. "We've been doing a retrospective review for several years and we've basically now presented our findings to the U.S. authorities," BNP Chief Financial Officer Lars Machenil told Reuters Insider TV. Standard Chartered agreed in 2012 to pay $327m (£196m) to resolve allegations that it violated US sanctions against Iran, Sudan, Burma and Libya. BNP shares were down 4.1% to €58.38, the biggest fall on the STOXX 600 Europe banks index. Reuters

webTitle: EasyJet boss Carolyn McCall gets £6.5m pay package

fields.standfirst: Vast majority of no votes on approving directors' pay came from founder Sir Stelios Haji-Ionannou and his family
fields.body:
Large institutional investors yesterday ensured the safe passage of a £6.5m pay package for EasyJet chief executive Carolyn McCall.

Some 45% of investors' votes were against approving directors' pay at the airline's annual meeting. But the vast majority of the no votes came from the founder and largest shareholder, Sir Stelios Haji-Ioannou, and his family. Other investors backed the payout.

McCall, who joined EasyJet in 2010, this year netted a long-term incentive payment of £4.5m on top of her £665,000 salary and bonus.

Haji-Ioannou has been somewhat mollified by the departure of his long-standing foe, chairman Mike Rake, and by the award of two dividends. He backed motions at the Luton AGM to approve an ordinary and special dividend which will net him around £80m.

Despite the substantial increase in the airline's share price, which has more than trebled in the last two years, Haji-Ioannou remains critical of excessive boardroom pay and wary of expansion plans, with EasyJet having placed an order for 135 Airbus A320s last June.

A spokesman for Stelios said: "The pay package is unfinished business and we reserve the right to take it up again if unnecessary."

EasyJet launched the first flights of a new service from Luton to Venice yesterday, with further expansion on domestic routes in Italy expected in coming months.

webTitle: FTSE falters after six days of rises, hit by warnings from Tate and Rolls-Royce

fields.standfirst: Mixed day for corporate news sees positive news from Imperial and Shire
fields.body:
After six days of rises, leading shares were hit by some poor trading updates, some profit taking and disappointing US retail sales.

The cumulative effect of all that was to knock 15.61 points off the FTSE 100 to leave it at 6659.42, although it recovered from its lows following an opening gain on Wall Street.

Tate and Lyle took the wooden spoon. The sweetener specialist cut its estimate for the full year to below City expectations, sending its shares tumbling 126.5p to 660p.

The company, which supplies sweeteners and other ingredients to food and drink makers, blamed weak sales in developed markets and a drop in sucralose prices.

Meanwhile Rolls-Royce dropped 165p to £10.45 after it said sharp cuts in defence spending in the US and Europe would mean no profit growth in 2014. The news dragged BAE Systems 13.7p lower to 425.8p.

Lloyds Banking Group lost 2.21p to 81.32p despite moving to a full year profit as the sector remained out of favour.

On the other side of the coin, Imperial Tobacco jumped 126p to £23.51 following a well received update.

Shire edged up 1p to £31.42 after the pharmaceutical group said fourth quarter earnings rose 29% to a better than expected $510m. Full year income rose 23% to $1.86bn.

The figures were boosted by a strong performance from its rare disease drugs, while the group has also benefited from chief executive Flemming Ornskov's move to simplify the business and add on acquisitions.

But after early gains, Amec dipped 12p to £10.80 even though the company firmed up its $3bn bid for US rival Foster Wheeler, announced a bigger than expected dividend and a record order book. Its full year profits rose 3% rise to £343m.

Aberdeen Asset Management fell 19.4p to 408.2p after Jefferies moved from hold to underperform. Analyst Jason Streets said:

We do not believe that the [deal to buy Scottish Widows] will achieve its stated aims nor will it compensate for the slowdown in the group's powerhouse [equities business]. Aberdeen's future prospects mean its earnings deserve, in our view, a lower multiple. The chief executive of Aberdeen sold a substantial number of shares just 16 days after announcing the deal to acquire Scottish Widows; we urge investors to follow his lead. We cut our target price to 350p and our rating to underperform.

Royal Mail rose 2p to 598p and Asos added 282p to £65.62 after both companies were added to the MSCI Europe index, widely followed by tracker funds. Cantor Fitzgerald calculated tracker demand at 30m shares for Royal Mail and just over 2m for Asos.

Among the mid-caps, IP Group, which commercialises intellectual property developed in universities and other academic establishments, rose 9.5p to 196.5p after strong demand for its 165p a share placing allowed it to lift the amount it planned to raise from £75m to £100m. At the same time IP announced one of its portfolio companies, software analytics business Actual Experience, had joined Aim. Actual soared to 245p compared to the 54.5p introduction price.

Film and television distribution group Entertainment One, which released films including American Hustle and 12 Years a Slave, added 7.5p to 334p after an upbeat trading statement. In a buy note Investec said:

A good 10 month interim management statement showing very strong momentum in both Film and TV, with full year earnings expected ahead of previous management expectations.

But Ladbrokes lost 5.5p to 145.7p after analysts at Davy cut from neutral to underperform in the light of possible regulation of gaming machines in betting shops. They said:

Regardless of the eventual regulatory outcome, our assessment of the valuations of William Hill and Ladbrokes has resulted in a rather surprising conclusion; we believe that the market is actually pricing in considerably more risk for William Hill than Ladbrokes at current levels. Indeed, it appears to us that Ladbrokes is actually trading at its fair value at present in the absence of regulatory change. This is in contrast to William Hill, which is trading at a 16% discount to our fair value on the same basis. That inconsistency does not make sense, particularly given Ladbrokes' higher exposure to machines and its higher operational gearing to falling machine revenue. Indeed, if the same level of risk was to be priced into Ladbrokes as we believe is currently being priced into William Hill, then our indicative valuation of Ladbrokes would be just 102p.

webTitle: Avon Products may face £80m bill to settle bribery investigation

fields.standfirst: Cosmetics company's sales down 10% as it reveals likely US settlement linked to developing markets, largely in China
fields.body:
The cosmetics company Avon Products said on Thursday that it faced a bill for up to $132m (£80m) to settle a US bribery investigation into the company's drive to expand overseas.

Avon, famous for its army of Avon Lady sales reps, has had problems regarding its Chinese business since 2008, just two years after it started trading in the country, when it launched an internal inquiry into allegations of improper payments in China.

In 2011 the US securities and exchange commission and the US justice department began an investigation under American law defined by the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The inquiries have so far cost Avon $300m.

The company, which sacked four senior executives in 2011, said on Thursday that there were no assurances that it would reach a settlement and if it did, the company could not estimate its timing.

The possible settlement of $132m, however, would be about $40m more than the group had set aside and $120m more than it first offered as a settlement.

The legal update came as Avon revealed worse than expected recent trading. Sales fell 10% to $2.7bn, while operating losses climbed to $17m.

In recent years Avon has been betting on emerging markets for growth to offset a decline in business in the US. But over the last three months trade has deteriorated in Mexico and Russia, and sales fell by half in China.

In north America, Avon's sales of beauty products were down 25%. The number of sales reps was down 17%.

A bright spot was Brazil, Avon's top market, where sales rose 6%, stripping out the impact of foreign exchange.

Avon's net loss narrowed to $69m, or 16 cents per share, from $162m.

The company's chief executive, Sheri McCoy, who took the reins almost two years ago with a promise to turn around the company, said in a statement: "Much works remains to be done."

webTitle: Lloyds bank, a normal bank? Normal-ish, very ish!

fields.bodyText: A normal bank? Up to a point, Mr Horta-Osório. Lloyds Banking Group is still 33% owned by the state, there is no dividend yet, the bills for PPI mis-selling are still arriving, and last year's statutory profits were thin at £415m. But, yes, a normal-ish bank is starting to emerge. The profits statement was stuffed with flattering measures like "underlying" profits and "pro forma" capital ratios and, viewed through these prisms, Lloyds' medium-term outlook is brightening. Sometime around 2015 Lloyds ought to have a healthier capital ratio up around 12%-13% on the regulator's strict "fully loaded" basis. And dividends, all being well, will resume this year. So, barring stock market drama, it ought to be a relatively simple process for George Osborne to sell the state's stake this year. Hedge funds and others who piled into the shares at 25p-30p at the end of 2011 have done well. They correctly gambled that Lloyds, the dominant force in UK domestic banking, could not fail to make a lot of money when warmer economic breezes arrived. Does the chief executive deserve a £1.7m bonus? António Horta-Osório is pushing his luck on that front. The recovery in the share price to 80p is undeniable. But it would have been classier to wait until dividends are actually declared, rather than merely intended. As Simon Walker, director general of the Institute of Directors, points out: "The reality is that no dividends have been paid to shareholders since the crisis." Indeed, lest we forget amid Horta-Osório's boasts about the "many accolades" received by Lloyds in 2013, the bank was also fined £28m by the regulator for its disgraceful "grand in the hand" scheme to encourage staff to stuff customers with investment products. Those events occurred in 2010 and 2011, so partly on Horta-Osorio's watch. Normal banks don't behave like that (we hope).

webTitle: Comcast announces $45.2bn takeover of Time Warner Cable

fields.standfirst: Deal will create 'world class media and technology company' – but there are fears it will hurt competition
fields.body:
The US media giant Comcast has agreed to buy rival Time Warner Cable in a $45.2bn (£25.5bn) deal that unites the country's two biggest cable TV operators and will control more than a third of the market.

Comcast, which owns the NBC broadcast network and the Universal film studio, offered $158.82-a-share to take over Time Warner Cable (TWC), the cable firm spun off from media group Time Warner in 2009.

Brian Roberts, chairman and CEO of Comcast, said consumers would benefit from the "really special transaction", adding that he was "optimistic" that regulators would allow it. But consumer groups were aghast at the deal, saying it was "unthinkable" that it could be approved.

"This combination will drive us to have faster innovation in the highly competitive and dynamic market," Roberts said during a conference call. He said the deal was "pro-consumer", and added: "We have no business overlap, there's no competition."

Roberts said cable companies faced increasing competition from telecom companies like Verizon and Google, which is providing broadband and TV to a small but growing number of US cities via its Google Fiber division.

But critics immediately charged the deal would further reduce competition in an already heavily consolidated market. Craig Aaron, president of internet rights lobby group Free Press said: "In an already uncompetitive market with high prices that keep going up and up, a merger of the two biggest cable companies should be unthinkable. This deal would be a disaster for consumers and must be stopped.

"This deal would give Comcast control of more than a third of the US pay-TV market and more than half of the US triple-play market for video, voice and internet service. Comcast will have unprecedented market power over consumers and an unprecedented ability to exert its influence over any channels or businesses that want to reach Comcast's customers."

The surprise takeover comes after TWC rejected a $60bn offer from smaller rival Charter Communications as "grossly inadequate". Charter had been pursuing for eight months.

The proposed deal, which will create a company with about 30m customers, is expected to face intense regulatory investigation due to its dominance of the market.

Comcast has about 22m video subscribers and TWC has about 12m, with a significant presence in New York. The companies said they were prepared to divest 3m TWC subscribers to help win approval of the deal. The new company would tower over its closest video competitor, DirecTV, which has about 20m video customers.

AT&T was forced to abandon its $39bn merger with T-Mobile in 2011 after the Justice Department sued, arguing the combination of the country's second-and fourth-largest wireless carriers would violate antitrust law and "substantially lessen competition".

Roberts said he would not have proceeded with the deal had Comcast not been confident a deal would pass competition rules. Comcast is a major player in Washington. Chief lobbyist and executive vice president David Cohen is a major Democrat fundraiser and attended the state dinner honoring French President Francois Hollande this week. President Barack Obama has played golf with Roberts.

"The combination of Time Warner Cable and Comcast creates an exciting opportunity for our company, for our customers, and for our shareholders, Roberts said in a statement. "In addition to creating a world-class company, this is a compelling financial and strategic transaction for our shareholders. Also, it is our intention to expand our buyback program by an additional $10bn at the close of the transaction."

Robert Marcus, chairman and CEO of TWC, said: "This combination creates a company that delivers maximum value for our shareholders, enormous opportunities for our employees and a superior experience for our customers.

"Comcast and Time Warner Cable have been the leaders in all of the industry's most important innovations of the last 25 years and this merger will accelerate the pace of that innovation."

The new company will be led by Neil Smit, the current CEO and president of Comcast Cable Communications.

If successful, the deal will be the second time in little more than a year that Comcast has helped reshape the US media landscape after its $17bn acquisition of NBC Universal was completed in 2013.

webTitle: Shire profits boosted by rare disease success

fields.standfirst: Pharmaceutical group upbeat on outlook after earnings come in ahead of forecasts
fields.body:
Following the lunchtime release of its results, Shire has joined the list of those companies deemed to have pleased the market.

The pharmaceutical group, best known for its Vyvanse hyperactivity treatment, said fourth quarter earnings rose 29% to a better than expected $510m. Full year income rose 23% to $1.86bn.

The figures were boosted by a strong performance from its rare disease drugs, while the group has also benefited from chief executive Flemming Ornskov's move to simplify the business and add on acquisitions. It has sold the skin specialist Dermagraft while buying US group ViroPharma last year to boost the rare disease portfolio. Ornskov said:

Shire has delivered excellent financial results in 2013 and now has the foundations in place for further future growth. Our sharpened strategic focus and strong operational discipline have enabled us to deliver double digit product sales growth and [earnings growth] in excess of 20%. We've generated strong cash flows during the year, which have helped us to strengthen our balance sheet.
We expect further news flow from our pipeline in 2014 from mid and late stage clinical studies. Today [we] announce that we expect to deliver a similar level of [earnings] growth in 2014.

Meanwhile finance director Graham Hetherington said he was stepping down in March, to spend more time with his family. Shire's shares hit a new record of £32.11 before slipping back from the peak. They are currently up 51p at £31.92. Analyst Peter Welford at Jefferies said:

The 2014 outlook for similar 23% growth suggests consensus upgrades of 3%-5%, in our view, with targets perhaps just above our current estimates. Longer term the attractive relative valuation drives our buy.
In a minor setback Firazyr will not be approved in Europe for ACE-I until Phase III results are available. After the recent setback for Vyvanse in depression and December 2013 equivocal Phase III lifitegrast data in dry eye, we still believe significant news flow could boost belief in Shire's longer-term organic growth prospects. We view Premiplex (peak $650m) to be perhaps the most overlooked programme, which "best case" could reduce complications for preterm infants triggering an accelerated regulatory filing after data in the first half of 2015.

webTitle: Tate & Lyle shares not so sweet amid China price war

fields.standfirst: Company anticipates profit slump as price of sucralose sweetener used in bestselling Splenda product continues decline
fields.body:

webTitle: Iberia pilots drop strike threat and accept 14% salary cut

fields.standfirst: Willie Walsh, head of Iberia and BA parent group IAG, says 'bold' deal was only way to save airline from decline
fields.body:
A deal has been struck with pilots at Iberia that International Airlines Group, the parent company of British Airways as well as Iberia, hopes will pave the way for swingeing changes at the Spanish carrier without further industrial action.

The agreement in principle between Sepla, the Spanish pilots' union, and IAG will freeze salaries, which were cut last year by 14%, until 2015 although a potential further 4% cut has been dropped under agreed "productivity improvements", IAG said. These include longer flying hours and a lower minimum wage.

Losses at the Spanish airline, which reached €1m (£820,000) a day last year, have largely wiped out profits IAG made at BA since the merger in 2011. IAG boss Willie Walsh said the survival of Iberia was at stake as he demanded more than 3,000 job cuts throughout the airline, and axed some routes, while developing a low-cost short-haul carrier, Iberia Express.

Walsh said Iberia's management and unions had struck a "bold deal". He added: "Permanent structural change was the only way to save Iberia from slow decline. This agreement marks the beginning of its future."

Two five-day strikes by Iberia staff over threats to their terms and conditions took place in early 2013, but talks have since averted further action.

Luis Gallego, Iberia's executive chairman, said: "This groundbreaking deal reduces the cost structure and provides the foundation for the airline to grow profitably. A strong and profitable Iberia can protect jobs in the long term and boost tourism which is a key driver in Barajas and Spain's economic recovery.

"Iberia is the natural airline choice for Latin America and this agreement will enable it to be a formidable competitor and build on its new brand, providing customers with great service and an extensive network.

"This agreement also enables the growth of Iberia Express with a competitive cost base and provides promotion opportunities for current Iberia and Iberia Express first officers. Iberia Express will help make Iberia profitable and stronger, by providing short-haul feed, and will provide Spanish competition to low-cost carriers."

The agreement in principle must still be approved by a wider union vote. Negotiations are continuing with other unions at Iberia representing ground staff and cabin crew.
